metadata.case_name: Shriniwas Krishnaji and Bhimabai v. S. N. Borkar and others

facts.text: M. B. Jakati, defendant No. 1, was the Managing Director of Dharwar Urban Co-operative Bank Limited which went into liquidation, receiving yearly remuneration of Rs. 1,000.
Payment order for Rs. 15,100 made by Deputy Registrar of Co-operative Societies against defendant No. 1 on April 21, 1942.
Bungalow belonging to M. B. Jakati attached by Collector under Bombay Land Revenue Code on July 27, 1942.
Notice for sale issued on November 24, 1942, proclamation on December 24, 1942, sale fixed for February 2, 1943.
Defendant No. 1 applied for postponing the sale on January 16, 1943, which was rejected.
Auction sale held on February 2, 1943, confirmed on June 23, 1943, purchaser S. N. Borkar, defendant No. 7, respondent No. 1.

Pedigree: Madhavarao Balakrishan Jakati (Deft. 1), Bhimabai (Deft. 2, later appellant No. 2), son Krishnaji (orig. Plff. 1), son Shriniwas (Appellant No. 1), daughters Shantibai (Deft. 3), Indumati (Plff. 1a? Deft. 4).

Krishnaji filed suit for partition on January 15, 1943, alleging sale not binding on joint family as avyavaharika debt, only father's right, title and interest sold under s. 155 Bombay Land Revenue Code, claiming 1/4 share.
Appellant No. 1 Shriniwas filed written statement on January 12, 1944, supporting partition and that sale not binding.
Respondent No. 1 sold property to defendants 8 to 10 (respondents 2 to 4) on February 10, 1944.
After Krishnaji's death, Shriniwas substituted as plaintiff on June 28, 1944; mother claimed his share as heir.

Trial Court (Civil Judge, Senior Division, Dharwar, judgment October 19, 1945): Suit not collusive, debt avyavaharika, declared 1/3 shares each to appellant No. 1, defendant No. 1, appellant No. 2 in joint family property including bungalow.
Bombay High Court (August 22, 1950): Debt not avyavaharika, whole estate sold under s. 155, sons had no interest left in bungalow, varied decree.

legal_issues.text: Whether the debt of the father was avyavaharika.
Whether institution of partition suit operated as severance, limiting sale to father's share.
What interest passed under auction sale u/s 155 Bombay Land Revenue Code: only father's or whole joint family estate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Debt was avyavaharika (misfeasance, illegal/immoral), so not binding on joint family, sons' interest did not pass.
Even if not avyavaharika, partition suit on Jan 15, 1943 severed status before sale, ending father's power over sons' share.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law on severance of joint status

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s. 155 Bombay Land Revenue Code, only right, title and interest of defaulter (father) sold, not sons' shares.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit collusive, instigated by father; debt binding as from bank remuneration, pious obligation on sons unless immoral/illegal proved.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Pious obligation under Hindu law; sons must prove immoral/illegal debt

respondent_arguments.text: Whole estate sold in execution, including sons' shares due to pious obligation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law; s. 155 Bombay Land Revenue Code

court_reasoning.text: Debt not avyavaharika; negligence as managing director not repugnant to good morals; Deputy Registrar's order not evidence of nature (s.43 Evidence Act); respondent's pleadings confirm negligence, not immoral.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Translation by Colebrooke: debt for cause repugnant to good morals; modern banking negligence not avyavaharika.

court_reasoning.text: Pious obligation of sons to pay father's non-avyavaharika debts continues post-partition; creditor can seize whole erstwhile joint property; partition changes mode of enjoyment but not liability (s.64 CPC analogy).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sons' pious duty unaffected by partition unless arrangement for debt payment; father represents sons in decree.

court_reasoning.text: Documents (attachment, notice, proclamation, confirmation, certificate) show whole bungalow sold, not fractional share; s.155 BLRC same as CPC 'right, title and interest'; question of fact what court intended to sell and purchaser bought.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Attachment and proclamation pre-suit; no protest by sons; purchaser paid for whole.

holdings.text: Liability of sons based on pious obligation continues post-partition; father's alienation power ends but creditor's right to seize whole unaffected.
In sales u/s 155 BLRC, what passes is factual: whole estate sold here.
Debt from managerial negligence not avyavaharika.
No need to implead sons post-partition in execution; sale valid absent proof of immoral debt.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hem Raj alias Babu Lal v. Khem Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Translation of avyavaharika as debt repugnant to good morals.

precedents_cited.case_name: Toshanpal Singh v. District Judge of Agra
precedents_cited.relevance: Criminal breach of trust avyavaharika, but civil unaccounted monies not.
Pious obligation basis of liability, continues post-partition.
Pious duty legalised, not irrespective of inheritance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suraj Bansi Koer v. Sheo Prasad Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Father's power to alienate for antecedent debt.
Sons cannot set up rights against creditor for non-immoral debt.
Purchaser defends title if whole sold; sons challenge only on immorality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidheshwar Mukherji v. Bhubneshwar Prasad Narain Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Pious obligation post-partition; creditor can attach sons' shares.

precedents_cited.case_name: Meenakshi Naidu v. Immudi Kanaka Rammaya Kounden
Shambu Nath Pandey v. Golab Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Fathers share alone when documents so indicate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Babu Mahabir Persad v. Rai Markunda Nath Sahai

precedents_cited.relevance: RTI of debtor conveys whole coparcenary.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Auction sale of right, title and interest of defaulter; same effect as CPC sale; factual what sold.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deputy Registrar's order not evidence of facts/merits.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Criminal breach of trust example of avyavaharika.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Attachment unaffected by change in mode of enjoyment post-partition.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Bombay High Court decree varying trial court's partition decree dismissed; held debt not avyavaharika, pious obligation continues post-partition suit, whole bungalow validly sold under s.155 BLRC to respondent No.1.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; respondents retain property.

key_quotes.text: "The translation of the term as given by Colebrooke makes the nearest approach to the true conception of the term used in the Smrithis texts and may well be taken to represent its correct meaning."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Destructive as it may be of the principle of independent coparcenary rights in the sons, the decisions have for sometime established the principle that the sons cannot set up their rights against their fathers alienation for an antecedent debt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms pious obligation over coparcenary rights.

key_quotes.text: "It is a question of fact in each case as to what was sold in execution of the decree."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines scope of sale under s.155 BLRC.
